overview: This measure has been amended to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [8] It now establishes a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits. [8] The Judiciary is now required to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Firth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [8]
appropriations: The committee has inserted an appropriation amount of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [8] The measure was amended to delete language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health for an unspecified number of temporary positions. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Third Circuit's proposal requests the bill to be amended to reflect a two-year program for the Big Island. [7] The proposal calls for all fourteen (14) of the women currently participating in the Kona BIDC program to be screened for eligibility for the KWC program. [7] This will allow the program to begin providing services to the target population immediately, instead of waiting for individual referrals to trickle in for a standalone program. [7]
agency_impact: The Third Circuit has submitted a detailed proposal for the establishment of a two-year Women’s Court pilot project in the Kona Division of the Third Circuit Court. [7] The Kona Women’s Court (“KWC”) program would operate as a separate program under the supervision of Big Island Drug Court (“BIDC”). [7] To be successful, the Judiciary states the program will require sufficient funding and positions, including a Women’s Mental Health Professional, a Kona Probation Supervisor, and a Drug Court Peer Specialist. [7]
economic_impact: Your Committee finds that Hawaii County has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women. [8] Testimony indicates that the poorest areas of the County have a median household income of only $50,313 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) per year. [7] This measure will support women in the State dealing with trauma, abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems. [8]
policy_impact: The measure was amended to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [9] A three-year Women's Court Pilot Program is now established in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits. [9] The requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study has been deleted and replaced with a requirement for the Judiciary to submit a report on the costs of a pilot program for the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [9]
revenue_sources: The Judiciary testimony proposes a two-year pilot program budget with a total cost of $1,071,900 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt). [7] The committee has amended the measure by inserting an appropriation amount of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027 from the general revenues of the State. [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Judiciary's testimony details a two-year pilot program budget for Kona with Year 1 costs of $514,900 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) and Year 2 costs of $557,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt). [7] Key annual costs requested in testimony include $175,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) for a Women's Mental Health Professional (1FTE), $100,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) for Womens Behavioral Health Beds, and $85,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) for a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor (1FTE). [7] The proposal also includes funding for a Peer Specialist (1FTE) at $80,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) per year and a Cultural Practitioner and Advisor at $30,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) per year. [7] Training costs are estimated at $5,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in year one and $42,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in year two for the Kona team to travel to the national All Rise conference. [7] The legislative document inserts appropriations matching these annual amounts for the Kona pilot. [8] The measure also makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will create ongoing fiscal obligations. [8] If the Kona pilot program is successful, the ultimate goal would be to expand the women’s court program to Hilo and make the program permanent. [7]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary testimony seeks funding for technology totaling $4,900 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) in the first year of the pilot program. [7] This includes a computer workstation in the probation waiting area for $1,200 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt), a computer and printer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt) each, and a laptop for work in rural communities for $1,200 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt). [7] Testimony also requests a cellphone for fieldwork at a cost of $500 (HB727_HD1_TESTIMONY_JDC_03-19-25_.PDF.txt). [7]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Given the success of the First District's Mohala Wahine, the Committee has inserted language making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, which will result in ongoing fiscal obligations. [8] If the Kona pilot program is successful, the ultimate goal would be to expand the women’s court program to Hilo and make the program permanent after the end of the 2-year project period. [7] This expansion would create additional, permanent fiscal liabilities for the State. [7]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The measure has been amended to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent. [9] The pilot program is now established in the Kona division of the Third Circuit rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits, based on a detailed proposal from the Judiciary for a two-year project. [9] The measure now includes specific appropriations of $514,900 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_SD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2026-2027 for the Kona pilot, and the previously noted funding request from the Department of Health has been deleted. [8] The program now specifically targets the fourteen (14) women currently participating in the Kona BIDC program. [7] A new reporting requirement directs the Judiciary to study the need and costs for a pilot program in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [9]
